many commentators argue often

links science and
documentary in terms of people's common
perception of it, is that there's often a tendency
to think of both of them

as offering unmediated access
onto the world out there.

So there's often
the strong tendency for people to see documentaries
simply a window onto reality,

the case for science,

sense that for many people the idea is that they like to
think of science as allowing

completely direct access to
the outer physical world. But many science
studies scholars would argue that
science doesn't just

simply offer unmediated
access onto the world. How do scientists
measure or monitor

or present the natural world? Often they have to do so
through technical instruments,

for example. And those instruments serve
as a form of mediation. And when scientists use those
instruments, for example,

or they might use visual
pictures or diagrams based on what those
instruments might say, those visual images also have
to be perceived or interpreted.

And this is
increasingly the case, given computer simulations. So for example, I
have a student who's working on the issue
of uranium mining.

And it used to be the
case that when people-- when geologists went off to
do work on uranium mining,

they would go off and do actual
field work at geological sites,

and that would be
the basis of work, but now increasingly
geologists are

relying on statistical
modeling to find out where they think that uranium
deposits might be, for example.

So there's an increasing way
with the use of computers and visual modeling that
visual images and diagrams

and pictures become
increasingly central to how science gets conveyed or talked
about or thought through.

So if you think about
those visual images, you always have it. How are those visual
images constructed? How do people
interpret those images?

How do they think through them? So there's all these kinds
of layers of interpretation and mediation that happened
through those kinds

of visual images. And then for scientists when
they want to talk or write about their work, or they
want to convey it to others,

we have to do it
through speaking, right? We rely upon the
language that we use. And there are certain
conventions then about, well,

how do you write up the science
that you're engaged in doing? How do you persuade
fellow scientists

that this is a good argument? What are the conventions
within your discipline about what makes a good
or convincing argument?

So all of these different kinds
of representation and language

help to mediate how we perceive
and understand the world that we're part of. In addition to whatever
our own personal kind

of social positioning or
institutional positioning might be. And similarly documentary
film theorists would argue that
documentary film also

doesn't offer just
simply unmediated access onto the world. I mean, documentary films
are about the real world,

of what that real world is. So and again, it's not to
say that some interpretations

aren't better than others,
because some interpretations are better than others. But filmmakers do-- I
mean obviously filmmakers

choose their subjects. They choose what to
shoot, they choose what to exclude
from the frame, they

choose how to create a
narrative out of those images through the process of editing. And then you also have
the issue of the subjects

that documentary
filmmakers are filming, what are those subjects
interpretations of the world?

And then you have the
people who at the end view the film who have their
interpretations of what they think is going on.

So you have the subjects
who are being filmed, their interpretations and
mediations of the world. You have the filmmaker
creating mediations

of what's going on through
what the filmmaker is doing, and then you have the
people who watch it at the end who are interpreting
and meeting it at the same end.

So you have all these
kinds of different layers of interpretation that all
go on as people make and view

different names. Science studies, social
studies of science, STS, lots of other different
names we won't go into,

has been an interdisciplinary
venture by historians, philosophers, anthropologists,
sociologists, and others

momentum during the 1960s and '70s, and it's
offered a way to think

about science in social terms. To stand back a bit
from the science and think about what it is in
terms of the ideas at work.

Not only the ideas
at work, but also in terms of the
people who practice that science, the
communities and institutions

that they're part of. And these are important
social questions for us to be thinking about, right? Because science and
modern technologies

to our contemporary lives. They shape how we
live, how we think in the world, the kinds of
policy decisions that get made,

the health of our bodies,
the kinds of knowledge we consider valid. I mean so these
are all completely central social questions.

and philosophers, these kinds of
questions around science

out of our social world.

world in which we exist. Science gets produced by people

places in which we all exist, we ask certain

kinds of questions. The time periods in
which we're operating

It's a collective

pay attention to science as a process. What do scientists actually do?
